examples.code:
Show Dialog

The main message for the dialog box goes here. We can put any elements we like here. For example, a text input:

<ff-button @click="$refs['dialog1'].show()">Show Delete Dialog</ff-button>
<ff-dialog ref="dialog1" header="My Other Dialog Box" @confirm="doSomething()" confirm-label="Delete" kind="danger">
	Are you sure you want to delete this?
</ff-dialog>

<ff-button @click="$refs['dialog2'].show()">Show Custom Dialog</ff-button>
<ff-dialog ref="dialog2" header="My Custom Dialog Box">
	<template v-slot:default>
		Note we can override the actions too, but need to include close logic
	</template>
	<template v-slot:actions>
		<ff-button kind="secondary" @click="$refs['dialog2'].close();doSecondaryAction1()">Secondary 1</ff-button>
		<ff-button kind="secondary" @click="$refs['dialog2'].close();doSecondaryAction2()">Secondary 2</ff-button>
		<ff-button kind="danger" @click="$refs['dialog2'].close();doSomething()">Confirm</ff-button>
	</template>
</ff-dialog>

props.description: <string> to display in the main header bar of the dialog box
The text contained within the primary button of the dialog box.
The 'kind' to set on the primary button. Recommended as 'primary' or 'danger'.
Boolean to control the disabled state of the primary confirm button.

slots.name: default
slots.description: Define the core content of the dialog.

slots.name: actions
slots.description: Replace the default secondary/primary button layout. In this case, @confirm and @cancel will not emit.

emits.description: When the primary action button is selected, this event is triggered.
When the secondary action button is selected, this event is triggered.
